overview: What company benefits you'll pay tax on, eg company cars, low-interest loans and accommodation, and what company benefits are tax-free, eg childcare.
title: Tax on company benefits

table.body:
You pay tax on company benefits like cars, accommodation and loans. 

You pay tax on the **value** of these benefits to you.

How much tax you pay can depend on how much you earn. You'll always pay tax on company benefits if:

- you're a company director
- you earn £8,500/yr or more (including the value of your benefits)

Some company benefits can be tax-free, eg childcare and canteen meals.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
^You pay tax on the **value** of the benefit to you.^

##Company cars
Your company car's value depends on things like its list price and the type of fuel it uses. Its value is lessened if you have the car part-time or if you pay something towards its cost.

If your employer pays for your personal fuel you'll pay tax on this separately.

Use the [company car fuel benefit calculator](http://cccfcalculator.hmrc.gov.uk/CCF0.aspx "Company car fuel benefit calculator"){:rel="external"} on the HM Revenue & Customs website.

$D
[Download car benefits and car fuel benefits helpsheet (PDF, 211KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/helpsheets/hs203.pdf "Car benefits and car fuel benefits helpsheet, PDF, 211KB"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Loans
Low-interest or interest-free loans from your employer are taxable if the total amount is £5,000 or more.

You pay tax on the difference between the interest rate you pay to your employer and the official rate of interest set by the Bank of England.

^You may pay tax if your employer lends money to one of your relatives.^

$D
[Download tax relief on loans helpsheet (PDF, 107KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/helpsheets/hs340.pdf "Help with tax relief on loans helpsheet, PDF, 107KB"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Living accommodation
If you (or one of your relatives) is living in accommodation provided by your employer you may pay tax. 

How the tax is worked out depends on whether the accommodation cost more than £75,000.

You may not pay tax if you get the accommodation so you can do your job, or do your job better (eg agricultural workers living on farms).

$D
[Download living accommodation helpsheet (PDF, 108KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/helpsheets/hs202.pdf "Living accommodation helpsheet, PDF, 108KB"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Medical insurance
You usually pay tax on the cost of the insurance premiums if your employer pays for your medical insurance.

You can get some tax-free health benefits from your employer, eg:

- medical insurance when you're working abroad
- annual check-ups 

^Find out [what counts as a benefit and how it is taxed](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/exb/a-z/a/index.htm "A-Z of taxable company benefits") on the HM Revenue & Customs website.^
table.title: Company benefits you'll pay tax on

table.body:
You can get some company benefits tax-free, including:

- meals in a staff canteen 
- hot drinks and water at work
- a mobile phone 
- workplace parking 
- Christmas parties
- childcare
table.title: Tax-free company benefits

table.body:
Usually your employer pays National Insurance contributions on any non-cash company benefits they give you.

Sometimes your company benefits are treated as normal earnings, eg cash vouchers. This means you’ll have to pay National Insurance contributions on them. 

Find out whether you'll pay [National Insurance contributions on a company benefit](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/exb/a-z/a/index.htm "A-Z of taxable company benefits"){:rel="external"} on the HM Revenue & Customs website.
table.title: National Insurance on company benefits
